chapter.title: Configuring Clients to Use ⪪
chapter.para: Any machine running &sle; 10 SP4, 11 SP1 or later, or any version of &sle; 12 can be configured to register against ⪪ and download software updates from there, instead of communicating directly with &scc; or Novell Customer Center.

If your network includes an ⪪ server to provide a local update source, you need to equip the client with the server's URL. As client and server communicate via the HTTPS protocol during registration, you also need to make sure the client trusts the server's certificate. In case you set up your ⪪ server to use the default server certificate, the CA certificate will be available on the ⪪ server at http://FQDN/smt.crt .

If the certificate is not issued by a well-trusted authority, the registration process will import the certificate from the URL specified as regcert parameter (&sls; 10 and 11), or, for SLE 12, the certificate will be downloaded automatically from ⪪. In this case, the client displays the new certificate details (its fingerprint), and you need to accept the certificate.
There are several ways to provide the registration information and to configure the client machine to use ⪪:

listitem.para: Provide the required information via kernel parameters at boot time ().
Configure the clients using an &ay; profile ().
Use the clientSetup4SMT.sh script (). This script can be run on a client to make it register against a specified ⪪ server.

chapter.para: These methods are described in the following sections.

sect1.title: Using Kernel Parameters to Access an ⪪ Server

important.title: regcert Parameter Support
important.para: Note that the regcert kernel boot parameter is supported for SLE 10 and 11. It is not supported from SLE 12.

sect1.para: Any client can be configured to use ⪪ by providing the following kernel parameters during machine boot: regurl and regcert. The first parameter is mandatory, the latter is optional.

warning.title: Beware of Typing Errors
warning.para: Make sure the values you enter are correct. If regurl has not been specified correctly, the registration of the update source will fail.

If an invalid value for regcert has been entered, you will be prompted for a local path to the certificate. In case regcert is not specified, it will default to http://FQDN/smt.crt with FQDN being the name of the ⪪ server.

listitem.para: For SLE 11 and older clients, the URL needs to be in the following format: https://FQDN/center/regsvc/ with FQDN being the fully qualified host name of the ⪪ server. It must be identical to the FQDN of the server certificate used on the ⪪ server. Example:

warning.title: Change of ⪪ Server Certificate
warning.para: If the ⪪ server gets a new certificate from an untrusted CA, the clients need to retrieve the new CA certificate file.

On SLE 10 and 11, this is done automatically with the registration process but only if a URL was used at installation time to retrieve the certificate, or if the regcert parameter was omitted and thus the default URL is used. If the certificate was loaded using any other method, such as floppy or local path, the CA certificate will not be updated.
On &sls; 12, after the certificate has changed, &yast; displays a dialog for importing a new certificate. If you confirm importing the new certificate, the old one is replaced with the new one.

sect1.title: Configuring Clients with &ay; Profile
sect1.para: Clients can be configured to register with ⪪ server via &ay; profile. For general information about creating &ay; profiles and preparing automatic installation, refer to the &ay; Guide. In this section, only ⪪ specific configuration is described.
To configure ⪪ specific data using &ay;, follow the steps for the relevant version of ⪪ client.

step.para: As &rootuser;, start &yast; and select Miscellaneous Autoinstallation to start the graphical &ay; front-end.
From a command line, you can start the graphical &ay; front-end with the yast2 autoyast command.
Open an existing profile using File Open , create a profile based on the current system's configuration using Tools Create Reference Profile , or work with an empty profile.
Select Software Novell Customer Center Configuration . An overview of the current configuration is shown.
Click Configure.

Set the URL of the ⪪ Server and, optionally, the location of the ⪪ Certificate. The possible values are the same as for the kernel parameters regurl and regcert (see ). The only exception is that the ask value for regcert does not work in &ay;, because it requires user interaction. If using it, the registration process will be skipped.
Perform all other configuration needed for the systems to be deployed.
Select File Save As and enter a file name for the profile, such as autoinst.xml.
As &rootuser;, start &yast; and select Miscellaneous Autoinstallation to start the graphical &ay; front-end.
From a command line, you can start the graphical &ay; front-end with the yast2 autoyast command.
Open an existing profile using File Open , create a profile based on the current system's configuration using Tools Create Reference Profile , or work with an empty profile.
Select Software Product Registration . An overview of the current configuration is shown.
Click Edit.

Check Register the Product, set the URL of the ⪪ server in Use Specific Server URL Instead of the Default, and you can set the Optional SSL Server Certificate URL. The possible values for the server URL are the same as for the kernel parameter regurl. For the SSL certificate location, you can use either HTTP or HTTPS based URLs.
Perform all other configuration needed for the systems to be deployed, then click Finish to return to the main screen.
Select File Save As and enter a file name for the profile, such as autoinst.xml.

sect1.title: Configuring Clients with the clientSetup4SMT.sh Script in SLE 11 and 12
sect1.para: In SLE 11 and 12, the /usr/share/doc/packages/smt/clientSetup4SMT.sh script is provided together with ⪪. This script allows you to configure a client machine to use an ⪪ server. It can also be used to reconfigure an existing client to use a different ⪪ server.

note.title: Installation of wget
note.para: The script clientSetup4SMT.sh itself uses wget, so wget must be installed on the client.

important.title: Upgrade clientSetup4SMT.sh
important.para: If you migrated your client OS from an older &sle;, you need to check if the version of the clientSetup4SMT.sh script on your host is up to date. clientSetup4SMT.sh from older versions of ⪪ cannot manage ⪪ 12 clients. If you apply software patches regularly on your ⪪ server, you can always find the latest version of clientSetup4SMT.sh at <SMT_HOSTNAME>/repo/tools/clientSetup4SMT.sh.

sect1.para: To configure a client machine to use ⪪ with the clientSetup4SMT.sh script, follow these steps:

step.para: Copy the clientSetup4SMT.sh script from your ⪪ server to the client machine. The script is available at <SMT_HOSTNAME>/repo/tools/clientSetup4SMT.sh and /srv/www/htdocs/repo/tools/clientSetup4SMT.sh. You can download it with a browser, using wget, or by another means, such as with scp.
As &rootuser;, execute the script on the client machine. The script can be executed in two ways. In the first case, the script name is followed by the registration URL; for example:
In the second case, the script uses the --host option followed by the host name of the ⪪ server, and --regcert followed by the URL of the SSL certificate; for example:
In this case, without any namespace specified, the client will be configured to use the default production repositories. If --namespace groupname is specified, the client will use that staging group.
The script downloads the server's CA certificate. Accept it by pressing Y.
The script performs all necessary modifications on the client. However, the registration itself is not performed by the script.
The script downloads and asks to accept additional GPG keys to sign repositories with.

important.title: Extension and Module Registration in &sle; 12
important.para: When registering an existing system against ⪪ 12—both on the command line and using &yast;—you need to register additional extensions and modules separately, one by one. This applies both to already installed extensions and to extensions that you plan to install.

sect2.title: Problems Downloading GPG Keys from the Server
sect2.para: The apache2-example-pages package includes a robots.txt file. The file is installed into the Apache2 document root directory, and controls how clients can access files from the Web server. If this package is installed on the server, clientSetup4SMT.sh fails to download the keys stored under /repo/keys.
You can solve this problem by either editing robots.txt, or uninstalling the apache2-example-pages package.

sect2.para: To configure a client to perform the registration against an ⪪ server use the &yast; registration module (yast2 inst_suse_register).
Click AdvancedLocal Registration Server and enter the name of the ⪪ server plus the path to the registration internals (/center/regsvc/), for example:

warning.para: If a staging group is used, make sure that settings in /etc/suseRegister.conf are done accordingly. If not already done, modify the register= parameter and append &namespace=namespace. For more information about staging groups, see .

sect2.title: Configuring Clients with &yast; in SLE 12
sect2.para: To configure a client to perform the registration against an ⪪ server use the &yast; Product Registration module yast2 registration (&sls; 12 SP1 or newer) or yast2 scc (&sls; 12).
On the client, the credentials are not necessary and you may leave the relevant fields empty. Click Local Registration Server and enter its URL. Then click Next until the exit from the module.

sect1.title: Listing Accessible Repositories
sect1.para: To retrieve the accessible repositories for a client, download repo/repoindex.xml from the ⪪ server with the client's credentials. The credentials are stored in /etc/zypp/credentials.d/SCCcredentials (&sls; 12) or /etc/zypp/credentials.d/NCCcredentials (&sls; 11) on the client machine. repoindex.xml returns the complete repository list as they come from the vendor. If a repository is marked for staging, repoindex.xml lists the repository in the full namespace (repos/full/$RCE).
To get a list of all repositories available on the ⪪ server, use the credentials specified in the [LOCAL] section of /etc/smt.conf on the server as mirrorUser and mirrorPassword.

sect1.title: Online Migration of &sle; Clients
sect1.para: &sle; clients registered against ⪪ can be migrated online to the latest service pack of the same major release the same way as clients registered against &scc; or Novell Customer Center. Before starting the migration, make sure that ⪪ is configured to provide the correct version of repositories to which you need the clients to migrate.

sect1.title: How to Update Red Hat Enterprise Linux with ⪪
sect1.para: ⪪ enables customers that possess the required entitlements to mirror updates for Red Hat Enterprise Linux (RHEL). Refer to for details on &sls; Subscription with Expanded Support. This section discusses the actions required to configure the ⪪ server and clients (RHEL servers) for this solution.
